arm_group.description: Twelve week skills based group therapy include four modules: mindfulness, emotion regulation, distress tolerance, and walking the middle path
The comparison group used in the present study is based on a publicly available treatment manual from the Services for Teens At Risk (STAR) Center at the University of Pittsburgh

brief_summary.textblock:
Youth with depressive symptoms are at risk for a range of problems later in life.  This
      includes problematic interpersonal relationships, occupational stress, and the occurrence of
      adult mental disorders.  The main purpose of this study is to test how effective two types
      of group therapy are at reducing depressive symptoms in youth.  A focus on group therapy is
      important because group therapy allows for many youth to be treated in a short amount of
      time.  Group therapy is also helpful because youth can get social support and feel less
      alone in their symptoms when they participate in group.  This study compares two groups, one
      that targets skills for managing difficult emotional experiences (dialectical behavior
      therapy skills group) and another group focuses on psychoeducation and is based on a
      publicly available treatment manual from the Services for Teens At Risk (STAR) Center at the
      University of Pittsburgh. The results of this study will provide insights regarding the
      comparative efficacy of these two treatments, and regarding predictors of treatment
      response.

clinical_study.brief_title: Group Treatment for Adolescents With Depression

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  English speaking

          -  male or female, ages 14 to 19, all races and ethnicities

          -  Current depression as assessed by an ALIFE - PSR score equal to or greater than 4

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Current manic episode

          -  current psychosis

clinical_study.official_title: Group Treatment for Adolescents With Depression

primary_outcome.description: Measure mood symptom severity. Response is defined as greater than or equal to 50% reduction in CDRS-R score
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to endpoint (assessed at weeks 0, 12, 24)

primary_outcome.description: Used to track symptom severity, treatment (both psychosocial and psychotropic), self-injurious/suicidal behavior and psychosocial functioning over time.
primary_outcome.measure: The Longitudinal Interval Follow-up Evaluation for adolescents (A-LIFE)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to endpoint (assessed at weeks 0, 12 and 24)

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Used to measure adverse events that have happened up until the 18th year of life
Used to ascertain adolescent and parent reported affect regulation, during the preceding year or time since last assessment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to endpoint (assessed at weeks 0, 4, 12 and 24)

secondary_outcome.description: Used to ascertain 80 adolescent and parent reported negative life events, during the preceding year or time since last assessment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to endpoint (assessed at weeks 0, 4, 12, and 24)

secondary_outcome.description: This is a self-reported questionnaire used to assess adaptive and maladaptive ways to cope with negative emotions or problematic situations
secondary_outcome.measure: The DBT Ways of Coping Checklist
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change for baseline to endpoint (assessed at weeks 0, 4, 12, and 24)

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
